Wait. What? The one major thing fueling climate change is the fossil fuel industry and yes that includes every stock portfolio currently making money off of fossil fuels in any way. That's it. It's not a existential crisis. It's an economic one. Policy gets shot down by lobbiests and officials, who support the fossil fuel industry/are supported by the fossil fuel industry. R&D gets covered up or defunded by it. And that on both sides of the isle, democrats and republicans. People are going to fight like hell to make money off of every drop of fuel we have before they will be ready to convert. So if the US gov't is willing to regulate the shit out of GHG and fossil fuel and invest in robust, publically funded R&D and business development (like everyone did during WW2 and many EU countries still hold stock in successfully deployed companies without bogging down growth) we might have a chance. Everyone go work for the gov't. The Dept. of Energy is literally holding a "Natural Gas" convention this week to celebrate the industry and its many successes. 😢

Natural Gas is better than other options right now. We do not have the battery and grid technology to support “clean energy” at this point. We could start building nuclear plants, which would be a huge help, but those take years to get online.

If the countries who largely produced emissions, like China, switched to Natural Gas we’d cut emissions immensely. We can’t just “ban” all forms of fossil fuels. There is simply no way to support a 1st world country that way. The R&D is certainly happening. The biggest stopgaps for clean energy are storing and transferring it. Failure to calculate peak energy use is part of why CA is having rolling blackouts. Ridiculous imo.

No ones covering up battery R&D either, literally billions are invested every year and there’s been some huge strides. Look at Tesla for example lol.

Even if we had a perfect way to store clean energy, it’d still be very inefficiency to store it vs operate other forms of peak power production, like nuclear or natural gas.

I think it’s easy to blame the fossil fuel industry for this, but at the same time the USA has done a pretty damn good job at cutting our emissions and were not even the biggest player. This is a global problem, not American lobbyist problem.

Also, beyond the hundreds of billions being invested in clean energy by governments around the world, super majors like Chevron and Shell are spending billions to “diversify” and build the future of energy to stay in business. They’re not doing a very good job at defunding it lol

I think the most obvious thing we could do is upgrade our grid to actually be able to support clean tech for the states that are using fossil fuels b/c solar and wind arent options. Yes, there are some lobbying issues here, but at the same time it’s an incredibly complex issue and we’re doing studies to figure out how to do it in a secure way. It won’t happen overnight. In the meantime, natural gas isn’t a horrible idea.

At the risk of oversimplifying, there are maybe three parts to getting political change to happen for an average member of the public - understanding climate change, understanding how your interests fit into the broader issue, and deciding whether to mobilize/figuring out how to mobilize 

There are problems at each of these points. The constant apocalypse talk for the past 30 years hasn't helped in part 1 of understand CC.

For understanding how your interests fit in, there's an issue of legibility for the climate advocate side which is less of an issue for the opposition. Especially for fossil fuel companies, they can boil all nuances down to some rough estimate of profit.

I’d also argue that Paris Accords aren’t that impactful in nations where it really counts. China is currently running 60% coal and is roughly 25% of the worlds emissions. USA has been decreasing emissions and China is continuing to increase. It might impact other western nations if we reassert ourselves, but I’m not sure China is going to suddenly change their behavior. Same thing applies to India and indonesia etc. who are now picking up manufacturing slack as China moves to a consumer economy

And mobilization, I think, is the most important in our current political paradigm. People have a lot of shit going on lmao. Many people believe in CC but don't get out to vote, go to public utility commissions, go to town halls, etc.

messages.content:
That guy has some good videos on setting up Home Assistant and using it for plant monitoring but I'm experienced with HA and there's a few things I would do different. 

First he never really goes in depth with his automations. I personally use NodeRed for my HA automations because it's a graphical interface and has a lot of extra functionally. I think it would be interesting to use an algorithm to give the plants as close to a perfect environment as possible.

Second, he links a lot of products like the TP-Link smart plugs. These are what I'll call "name brand" and pretty costly. There's a exploit in a lot of IOT devices (known as Tuya-Convert) that enables the user to flash the esp wifi chip with local firmware. This makes it a lot more responsive by taking it out of the cloud. These Tuya-Convertable devices are also a lot cheaper than the TP-Link devices he talks about, so if you were doing it on a larger scale it would add up quick.

Yes, exactly. We use the interchange (merchant) fees that typically funds rewards like cash back, points, or air miles, and instead put that to work in offsets and carbon removal credits.
Thank you! So if I understand right,  the amount spent on offsets is determined by total spending, and is not affected by how carbon-intensive your purchases are.

Correct. The way the math shakes out, the flat offset rate we apply should be more than enough to bring the average American consumer I to carbon negative territory. That said, if you’re a frequent flyer or drive a F-650 super duty truck (~7mpg), you might still net out carbon positive, in which case we’ll give you the option to purchase the offsets you’d need to get back to carbon neutral at the end of each month / billing cycle.

Has anyone here read Ministry for the Future?  If not, I'd highly recommend it.

For now, I think the best way to fight climate change is Nuclear power, It is really that simple, we want an alternative to fossil fuels, I'm sadly the one to report the most viable option is a non-renewable, yet carbon neutral, alternative known as 'uranium' and 'plutonium'. In the long term, yes, we need to learn to harness the power of the sun (which is, ironically, powered by nuclear fusion). Before that, however, we should just accept that the best bet is to smash some rocks together and watch them burn.

Coal and oil are awful power sources in the modern day. Their extraction is difficult and dangerous, their use is killing our planet, and their fumes end human life. Uranium and plutonium are comparatively easy to dig up, they don't cause global warming, and they only offer a risk to humans when handled improperly.

We can power ourselves for centuries off of the miracle of nuclear power, and in doing so we will drastically reduce the amount of damage we are causing our world. That precious time will almost certainly allow us to convert smoothly and properly to powers from solar sources.
